title: About the NIH Human Virome Program
description: The NIH Human Virome Program (HVP) is a comprehensive initiative to characterize the human virome across diverse populations and body sites.

sections.title: Program Overview
sections.content: The NIH Human Virome Program (HVP) is a major research initiative designed to comprehensively characterize the human virome â€“ all viruses that exist within and on the human body. This program brings together researchers from multiple institutions to collect and analyze virome samples from diverse populations across various body sites. The goal is to establish a foundational understanding of the human virome in health and disease, and to develop resources, methods, and data that will benefit the broader scientific community.

sections.title: Program Goals
sections.content:
The primary goals of the NIH Human Virome Program include:

- Establishing a comprehensive catalog of viruses associated with the human body
- Developing standardized methods for virome sample collection and analysis
- Creating reference datasets and tools for the scientific community
- Understanding the role of viruses in human health and disease
- Exploring the relationships between the virome, microbiome, and host
- Building a collaborative research community focused on virome science

sections.title: Scientific Impact
sections.content: The HVP aims to transform our understanding of the human virome and its impact on health. Recent research has linked virome changes to conditions including inflammatory bowel disease, diabetes, and various neurological disorders. By characterizing the virome across diverse populations and body sites, the HVP will provide insights into how viruses contribute to human biology and disease, potentially leading to new diagnostic approaches, therapeutic targets, and prevention strategies.

sections.title: Ethical, Legal, and Social Implications
sections.content:
The HVP addresses important ethical, legal, and social implications through:

- **Data Privacy**: Standardized consent forms and anonymization protocols protect participant information
- **Sample Ownership**: Clear policies define rights and access to collected specimens
- **Incidental Findings**: Standard protocols for reporting and verifying unexpected virus discoveries
- **Equity and Inclusion**: Targeted strategies ensure diverse representation in sample collection
- **Results Communication**: Structured plans for sharing findings with participants and the public
- **Commercial Applications**: NIH policies guide intellectual property and commercial translation
- **Scientific Responsibility**: Peer review and data validation ensure accurate representation of findings
